No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 433]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 558]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 602]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 729, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 60.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[489, 41, 507, 58]]<|/det|>
## 2  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 74, 128, 91]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 103, 640, 532]]<|/det|>
acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81 \text{m s}^{- 2}\) speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00 \times 10^{8} \text{m s}^{- 1}\) elementary charge \(e = 1.60 \times 10^{- 19} \text{C}\) unified atomic mass unit \(1 \text{u} = 1.66 \times 10^{- 27} \text{kg}\) rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67 \times 10^{- 27} \text{kg}\) rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11 \times 10^{- 31} \text{kg}\) Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02 \times 10^{23} \text{mol}^{- 1}\) molar gas constant \(R = 8.31 \text{J K}^{- 1} \text{mol}^{- 1}\) Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38 \times 10^{- 23} \text{J K}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant \(G = 6.67 \times 10^{- 11} \text{N m}^{2} \text{kg}^{- 2}\) permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85 \times 10^{- 12} \text{F m}^{- 1}\) \(\left(\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}}\right) = 8.99 \times 10^{9} \text{m F}^{- 1})\) Planck constant \(h = 6.63 \times 10^{- 34} \text{J s}\) Stefan- Boltzmann constant \(\sigma = 5.67 \times 10^{- 8} \text{W m}^{- 2} \text{K}^{- 4}\)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 565, 170, 582]]<|/det|>
## Formulae  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 598, 324, 615]]<|/det|>
uniformly accelerated motion  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 650, 252, 667]]<|/det|>
hydrostatic pressure  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 682, 154, 698]]<|/det|>
upthrust  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 723, 341, 741]]<|/det|>
Doppler effect for sound waves  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 761, 208, 778]]<|/det|>
electric current  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 793, 230, 810]]<|/det|>
resistors in series  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 828, 240, 845]]<|/det|>
resistors in parallel  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 98, 640, 532]]<|/det|>
\[g = 9.81 \text{m s}^{-2}\] \[c = 3.00 \times 10^{8} \text{m s}^{-1}\] \[e = 1.60 \times 10^{-19} \text{C}\] \[1 \text{u} = 1.66 \times 10^{-27} \text{kg}\] \[m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67 \times 10^{-27} \text{kg}\] \[m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11 \times 10^{-31} \text{kg}\] \[N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02 \times 10^{23} \text{mol}^{-1}\] \[R = 8.31 \text{J K}^{-1} \text{mol}^{-1}\] \[k = 1.38 \times 10^{-23} \text{J K}^{-1}\] \[G = 6.67 \times 10^{-11} \text{N m}^{2} \text{kg}^{-2}\] \[\epsilon_{0} = 8.85 \times 10^{-12} \text{F m}^{-1}\] \[\left(\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}}\right) = 8.99 \times 10^{9} \text{m F}^{-1})\] \[h = 6.63 \times 10^{-34} \text{J s}\] \[\sigma = 5.67 \times 10^{-8} \text{W m}^{-2} \text{K}^{-4}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 598, 581, 636]]<|/det|>
\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 650, 551, 668]]<|/det|>
\[\Delta p = \rho g\Delta h\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 680, 544, 698]]<|/det|>
\[F = \rho gV\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 712, 555, 747]]<|/det|>
\[f_{0} = \frac{f_{s}V}{V\pm V_{s}}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 760, 554, 780]]<|/det|>
\[I = A n v q\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 791, 608, 810]]<|/det|>
\[R = R_{1} + R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 821, 615, 855]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{1}{R} = \frac{1}{R_{1}} +\frac{1}{R_{2}} +\ldots\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 72, 311, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 311, 89]]<|/det|>
Define power.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 133, 920, 151]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 163, 181, 182]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 163, 860, 183]]<|/det|>
Use the definition of power to show that the SI base units of power are \(\mathrm{kgm}^2 \mathrm{s}^{-3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 274, 920, 293]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 304, 146, 323]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 303, 695, 323]]<|/det|>
The intensity \(I\) of a sound wave moving through a gas is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[453, 333, 544, 351]]<|/det|>
\[I = f^2 A^2 v k\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 364, 460, 383]]<|/det|>
where \(f\) is the frequency of the wave,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[212, 381, 470, 400]]<|/det|>
A is the amplitude of the wave,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[212, 396, 435, 415]]<|/det|>
v is the speed of the wave

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 413, 185, 431]]<|/det|>
<label>and</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[212, 413, 544, 431]]<|/det|>
k is a constant that depends on the gas.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 444, 432, 462]]<|/det|>
Determine the SI base units of \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 720, 920, 740]]<|/det|>
<form>SI base units .................................................... [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 752, 920, 771]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 97, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
A rigid uniform beam of weight \(W\) is connected to a fixed support by a hinge, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 98, 878, 255]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 269, 591, 288]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 301, 920, 368]]<|/det|>
A compressed spring exerts a total force of 8.2 N vertically upwards on the horizontal beam. A block of weight \(0.30 \text{N}\) rests on the beam. The right-hand end of the beam is connected to the ground by a string at an angle of \(30^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. The tension in the string is \(4.8 \text{N}\). The distances along the beam are shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 378, 646, 397]]<|/det|>
The beam is in equilibrium. Assume that the hinge is frictionless.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 409, 144, 428]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 409, 178, 428]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 409, 759, 428]]<|/det|>
Show that the vertical component of the tension in the string is 2.4 N.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 504, 920, 522]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 534, 181, 553]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 534, 801, 553]]<|/det|>
By taking moments about the hinge, determine the weight \(W\) of the beam.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 764, 920, 784]]<|/det|>
<form>W = ....................................................... N

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[896, 765, 920, 784]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 797, 180, 816]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 797, 873, 816]]<|/det|>
Calculate the horizontal component of the force exerted on the beam by the hinge.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[520, 888, 920, 907]]<|/det|>
<form>force = .................................................... N

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[895, 889, 920, 907]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 777, 89]]<|/det|>
The spring obeys Hooke's law and has an elastic potential energy of 0.32 J.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 489, 120]]<|/det|>
Calculate the compression of the spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 272, 920, 289]]<|/det|>
<form>compression = .................................................... $m$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 272, 920, 289]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
The string is cut so that the spring extends upwards. This causes the beam to rotate and launch the block into the air. The block reaches its maximum height and then falls back to the ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 133, 920, 168]]<|/det|>
Fig. 2.2 shows part of the path of the block in the air shortly before it hits the horizontal ground.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[237, 175, 756, 323]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 341, 591, 359]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.2</label> <label>(not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 373, 920, 406]]<|/det|>
The block is at a height of \(0.090 \text{m}\) above the ground when it passes through point A. The block has a kinetic energy of \(0.044 \text{J}\) when it hits the ground at point B.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 402, 378, 420]]<|/det|>
Air resistance is negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 434, 183, 453]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 434, 920, 467]]<|/det|>
Calculate the decrease in the gravitational potential energy of the block for its movement from A to B.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[225, 592, 920, 610]]<|/det|>
decrease in gravitational potential energy = .................................................... J [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 623, 181, 642]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 623, 920, 656]]<|/det|>
Use your answer in (c)(i) and conservation of energy to determine the speed of the block at point A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[512, 858, 920, 876]]<|/det|>
<form>speed = .................................................... $\text{ms}^{-1}$ [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 72, 180, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 71, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
By reference to the force on the block, explain why the horizontal component of the velocity of the block remains constant as it moves from A to B.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 149, 920, 166]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 180, 180, 199]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 180, 816, 200]]<|/det|>
The block passes through point A at time \(t_{\mathrm{A}}\) and arrives at point B at time \(t_{\mathrm{B}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 210, 920, 260]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 2.3, sketch a graph to show the variation of the magnitude of the vertical component \(\nu_{\mathrm{Y}}\) of the velocity of the block with time \(t\) from \(t = t_{\mathrm{A}}\) to \(t = t_{\mathrm{B}}\). Numerical values of \(\nu_{\mathrm{Y}}\) are not required.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[361, 271, 636, 425]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 443, 534, 462]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 460, 920, 479]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 490, 920, 508]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 14]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
A block is pulled in a straight line along a rough horizontal surface by a varying force \(X,\) as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[237, 114, 756, 207]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 220, 532, 238]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 250, 920, 285]]<|/det|>
Air resistance is negligible. Assume that the frictional force exerted on the block by the surface is constant and has magnitude 2.0N.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 297, 751, 316]]<|/det|>
The variation with time \(t\) of the momentum \(p\) of the block is shown in Fig. 3.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[287, 326, 707, 604]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 622, 534, 640]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 654, 146, 672]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 654, 470, 672]]<|/det|>
State Newton's second law of motion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 715, 920, 733]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A beaker in air contains a liquid. The base of the beaker is in contact with the liquid and has area \(A\), as shown in Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[306, 112, 688, 262]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 276, 532, 295]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 308, 584, 327]]<|/det|>
The liquid has density \(\rho\) and fills the beaker to a depth \(h\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 339, 146, 358]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 339, 638, 357]]<|/det|>
By using the definitions of pressure and density, show that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 370, 534, 388]]<|/det|>
\[p = \rho gh\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 400, 920, 434]]<|/det|>
where \(p\) is the pressure due to the liquid that is exerted on the base of the beaker and \(g\) is the acceleration of free fall.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 682, 920, 701]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 714, 146, 733]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 714, 905, 733]]<|/det|>
Suggest why the equation in (a) does not give the total pressure on the base of the beaker.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 775, 920, 792]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Fig. 4.2 shows the variation of the total pressure inside the liquid with depth \(x\) below the surface.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[198, 112, 799, 361]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 380, 534, 398]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 411, 445, 428]]<|/det|>
Determine the density of the liquid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[504, 597, 920, 615]]<|/det|>
<form>density = ............................................... $kg m^{-3}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 598, 920, 615]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
A solid cylinder is held stationary by a wire so that the base of the cylinder is level with the surface of the liquid, as shown in Fig. 4.3.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[252, 112, 744, 275]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 293, 591, 312]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.3 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 325, 920, 359]]<|/det|>
The cylinder has length \(4.0 \times 10^{- 2} \text{m}\) and cross-sectional area \(3.7 \times 10^{- 4} \text{m}^2\). The tension in the wire is \(0.53 \text{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 371, 920, 405]]<|/det|>
The cylinder is now lowered and then held stationary by the wire so that the top of the cylinder is level with the surface of the liquid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 419, 465, 437]]<|/det|>
Calculate the new tension in the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[504, 653, 920, 672]]<|/det|>
<form>tension = .................................................... N [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 685, 920, 702]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 97, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 752, 91]]<|/det|>
An electromagnetic wave in a vacuum has a wavelength of \(8.4 \times 10^{- 6} \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 103, 180, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 102, 887, 121]]<|/det|>
State the name of the principal region of the electromagnetic spectrum for the wave.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[845, 133, 923, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 163, 181, 182]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 163, 566, 182]]<|/det|>
Calculate the frequency, in THz, of the wave.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 319, 920, 338]]<|/det|>
<form>frequency = ............................................... THz [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 351, 146, 369]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 351, 920, 384]]<|/det|>
An arrangement that uses a double slit to demonstrate the interference of light from a laser is shown in Fig. 5.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 392, 870, 610]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 625, 591, 644]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 5.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 657, 920, 705]]<|/det|>
The light from the laser has a wavelength of \(6.2 \times 10^{- 7} \text{m}\) and is incident normally on the slits. The separation of the two slits is \(a\). The slits and screen are parallel and separated by a distance of \(2.8 \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 718, 920, 752]]<|/det|>
An interference pattern of bright fringes and dark fringes is formed on the screen. The distance on the screen across 8 bright fringes is \(22 \text{mm}\), as illustrated in Fig. 5.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 761, 850, 897]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 915, 534, 933]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 5.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 947, 549, 961]]<|/det|>
9702/21/M/J/23

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 181, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

Fringe P is the central bright fringe of the interference pattern in **(b)**. Fringe Q and fringe R are the nearest dark fringe and the nearest bright fringe respectively to the right of fringe P, as shown in Fig. 5.2.

<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 848, 106]]<|/det|>
A metal wire in a circuit has a length of \(1.8 \text{m}\) and a cross-sectional area of \(1.5 \times 10^{- 6} \text{m}^2\). The total number of free electrons (charge carriers) in the wire is \(2.3 \times 10^{23}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
There is a current in the wire so that a charge of \(172 \text{C}\) moves past a fixed point in the wire in a time of 2.5 minutes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 165, 146, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 164, 808, 184]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 289, 920, 308]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]
